immediate hypersensitivity.des_en: A category of allergic reaction, triggered by specific allergens and involving IgE. The majority of allergic reactions to pollens, pets, dust, mold, food, and insect venom are of this type.

immunity.des_en: The body’s ability to resist infection and disease.

immunoglobulin E.des_en: The substance responsible for most allergic reactions.

immunologically privileged site.des_en: A part of the body—such as the eye or ovaries—where the immune system isn’t able to function because it may damage the tissue there.

immunosuppressant drug.des_en: Medication that stifles the body's immune response; often given after an organ transplant to prevent rejection of the new organ.

immunotherapy.des_en: Treating disease by enhancing or suppressing the body’s immune system.

impacted.des_en: Something firmly fixed into place, such as a wisdom tooth.

impaction.des_en: A mass of hardened feces blocking the rectum or colon.

impaired fasting glucose.des_en: Blood sugar levels that are higher than normal but not yet diabetic. This term is used when the high blood sugar levels are found with a fasting plasma glucose test.

impaired glucose tolerance.des_en: Blood sugar levels that are higher than normal but not yet diabetic. This term is used when the high blood sugar levels are found with an oral glucose tolerance test.

impedance hearing testing.des_en: A test that sends sound waves to the eardrum to determine if a problem in the middle ear is causing hearing loss.

implantable cardioverter defibrillator.des_en: A device implanted in the chest and connected to the heart that delivers a shock to stop a potentially deadly rhythm and restore a normal (sinus) rhythm.

inactivated vaccines.des_en: Vaccines containing microbes that have been killed, and, therefore, are unable to cause disease.

infectious arthritis.des_en: Arthritis caused by harmful organisms such as bacteria.

inferior myocardial infarction.des_en: Heart attack involving the back part of the heart-muscle wall.

inferior vena cava.des_en: The large vein that carries blood from the lower half of the body to the heart.

infiltrating cancer.des_en: A cancer that has spread from where it first developed into surrounding tissue.

inflammatory bowel disease.des_en: A general term for two disorders, ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease, that cause the intestines to become swollen and inflamed. Often referred to as IBD.

inhibitory neurochemical.des_en: A chemical that stops the transmission of a message from one nerve cell to another.

injectable fillers.des_en: Substances injected into the skin to fill in wrinkles or add plumpness to the lips.

innate immunity.des_en: The body’s basic defenses against disease or infection that are present from birth.

insulin-dependent diabetes.des_en: Now called type 1 diabetes. It occurs when the body doesn’t produce enough insulin to control blood sugar levels properly.

intense pulsed light.des_en: A device that emits broadband light to improve the look of the skin or remove unwanted hair.

interferons.des_en: Proteins made by the body to protect against viruses, bacteria, and other harmful agents.

interleukins.des_en: A group of substances that act as messengers in the immune system.

intermediate-density lipoprotein.des_en: A type of lipoprotein. It consists of remnants of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) that eventually turn into low-density lipoprotein (LDL).

international unit.des_en: An internationally accepted amount of a substance based on its biological activity or effect; used as a measurement for fat-soluble vitamins.

interpersonal therapy.des_en: Short-term talk therapy focused on identifying and addressing problems in current relationships and building social skills.

intervention study.des_en: A study that compares one group that receives a medication or other therapy (an intervention) and another group does not (controls).

intervertebral disk.des_en: One of the small, shock-absorbing cushions located between the vertebrae of the spine.

intracerebral hemorrhage.des_en: A hemorrhagic stroke caused by the rupture of a blood vessel and subsequent bleeding into the brain tissue.

intraocular lens.des_en: A small artificial lens permanently fixed inside the eye to replace the natural lens during cataract surgery.

intrinsic sphincter deficiency.des_en: Inability of the urinary sphincter to close completely.

iodides.des_en: Salt compounds containing iodine that are used to control severe hyperthyroidism in special circumstances. They work by decreasing the thyroid gland’s production and secretion of thyroid hormone.

irritants.des_en: Substances such as tobacco, wood smoke, perfumes, and others that cause allergy-like symptoms, although the response is not an allergic reaction.

ischemic heart disease.des_en: The most common form of heart disease, in which narrowed or blocked coronary arteries have difficulty supplying sections of the heart muscle with the blood they need (ischemia).

ischemic stroke.des_en: A stroke caused by an interruption in the flow of blood to the brain; almost always caused by a blood clot blocking a blood vessel.

islets of Langerhans.des_en: Clusters of hormone-producing cells, including alpha and beta cells, that appear throughout the pancreas.

isolated systolic hypertension.des_en: A form of high blood pressure (hypertension) characterized by elevated systolic blood pressure and normal diastolic pressure.

IU.des_en: Commonly used abbreviation for international unit, an internationally accepted amount of a substance based on its biological activity or effect; used as a measurement for fat-soluble vitamins.

jet lag.des_en: A feeling of fatigue that occurs as the biological clock resets itself after traveling across time zones, usually by airplane.

julienne.des_en: To cut food into thin, matchstick strips.

Kegel.des_en: An exercise that helps prevent and treat incontinence by strengthening pelvic floor muscles.

keratectomy.des_en: A procedure in which a laser is used to correct vision problems by reshaping the cornea.

keratinocytes.des_en: Cells of the epidermis that produce a tough protein called keratin and form a soft, protective sheet for the body.

keratoderma blennorrhagica.des_en: A skin rash that sometimes occurs along with an autoimmune condition called Reiter's syndrome.

Keshan disease.des_en: Heart disease caused by a lack of selenium, an element that the body needs to function properly.

ketones.des_en: Substances produced when the body burns fat for energy or when the body doesn’t have enough insulin.

kidney failure.des_en: The final stage of chronic kidney disease. At this point, the kidneys can no longer eliminate waste products from the body.

kyphoplasty.des_en: A surgical procedure that eases or eliminates the pain of spinal fractures. It also restores vertebrae that have collapsed due to fractures to their normal size.

labile hypertension.des_en: Blood pressure that frequently fluctuates between normal and abnormal during the course of a day, often within only a few minutes.

lactic acidosis.des_en: A rare but potentially lethal condition in which blood lactic acid levels increase.

lactose intolerance.des_en: The inability of the body to easily digest lactose, a sugar found in milk and dairy products.

lacunar stroke.des_en: A small ischemic stroke caused by the blockage of one of the smaller blood vessels in the brain; the most common effect is weakness or disability on one side of the body.

lamellar bone.des_en: Hard, dense tissue that forms the outer shell of bones. Also called compact bone.

lamina.des_en: One of the two thin, plate-like parts of each vertebra.

Langerhans cells.des_en: Cells of the immune system that work in the skin to fight infection.

lanugo.des_en: Fine, soft hair that grows all over the body of a fetus and is typically shed before birth.

laser assisted uvula palatoplasty.des_en: A surgical procedure to ease snoring by removing or reshaping some of the tissues in the mouth (usually the uvula and soft palate) that vibrate and cause the noise of snoring.

laser hair removal.des_en: Permanent hair removal technique that uses a laser to target and heat melanin in the hair shaft, which damages the hair follicle.

laser photocoagulation.des_en: Surgery that uses a laser to seal off blood vessels in the eye; used to treat a number of eye diseases.

laser prostatectomy.des_en: A surgical technique for treating an enlarged prostate (benign prostatic hyperplasia). It uses a high-energy laser to remove large amounts of prostate tissue with little bleeding.

latex allergy.des_en: An allergic reaction to the proteins found in natural rubber.

LDL.des_en: Abbreviation for low-density lipoprotein. This so-called bad cholesterol can build up on artery walls, narrowing the artery and making a heart attack or stroke more likely.

learned insomnia.des_en: When fear of not sleeping develops after a short period of not sleeping well, and this anxiety causes ongoing trouble falling or staying asleep.

LED photomodulation.des_en: Use of a panel of light-emitting diodes (LEDs) to stimulate skin cells and improve the look of the skin.

left anterior descending coronary artery.des_en: One of the main arteries that supplies blood to the heart; it runs down the front surface of the heart.

left atrium.des_en: The left upper chamber of the heart.

left circumflex coronary artery.des_en: One of the main arteries that supplies blood to the heart; it curves around the back of the heart.

left ventricle.des_en: The left lower chamber of the heart. It pumps blood out of the heart to other organs in the body.

left ventricular hypertrophy.des_en: A thickening of the wall of the lower left chamber of the heart, which is responsible for pumping blood to organs throughout the body.

left-ventricular assist device.des_en: A surgically implanted pump that augments the pumping action of the left ventricle.

lensometer.des_en: A device used to check the prescription of eyeglasses.

leukotriene blockers.des_en: Asthma medications that work by blocking leukotrienes, chemicals made in the body as part of an allergic reaction.

leukotriene modifiers.des_en: Asthma medications that work by blocking the production or action of leukotrienes, chemicals made in the body as part of an allergic reaction.

leukotrienes.des_en: Chemicals that cause airways to swell when an allergic reaction occurs or in diseases like asthma.

levothyroxine sodium.des_en: A man-made version of the thyroid hormone thyroxine.

LH.des_en: Abbreviation for luteinizing hormone, a hormone that controls ovulation in women. In men, luteinizing hormone triggers production of testosterone.

ligature.des_en: Any material that is tied around a blood vessel to stop it from bleeding.

lignans.des_en: Antioxidant chemicals found in seeds like flax and sesame, as well as some fruits, vegetables, and grains.

limbic system.des_en: A group of structures in the brain that help control memory, emotions, sexual arousal, and motivation.

limbus.des_en: The border between the cornea and the white of the eye.

liothyronine sodium.des_en: A man-made version of the thyroid hormone triiodothyronine.

lipoatrophy.des_en: Dents or depressions in the skin that are caused by a loss of fatty tissue.

lipoprotein analysis.des_en: A test that measures the amount of triglycerides, total cholesterol, HDL (good cholesterol), and LDL (bad cholesterol) in a person’s blood.

lipoprotein(a).des_en: A molecule made up of fat and protein that is very similar to harmful LDL.

live attenuated vaccines.des_en: Vaccines made from a weakened virus or microbe. These weakened viruses and microbes don't cause disease; instead they teach the body to recognize the substance as harmful and destroy it if there is contact with it in the future.

living will.des_en: A legal document that states what a person would and wouldn’t want if he or she is no longer able to make health care decisions.

lobar hemorrhage.des_en: Bleeding that occurs in the white matter of the brain beneath the cerebral cortex.

locus ceruleus.des_en: An area of the brain stem that helps control the brain’s alertness, responses to certain stimuli, and stress and anxiety levels.

low-calorie diet.des_en: A weight-loss plan that limits calories to 800–1,500 a day.

low-density lipoprotein.des_en: So-called bad cholesterol. If there is too much LDL in the blood, it can collect on artery walls, narrowing them and making heart attacks and strokes more likely.

lower esophageal sphincter.des_en: A ring of muscle where the esophagus and stomach meet. It relaxes to let food into the stomach and closes to prevent stomach acids from backing up and irritating the esophagus.

lumbar spine.des_en: The lower portion of the spine. It includes the five lowermost bones (vertebrae) of the spine and is the start of the lower back.

lumbar stenosis.des_en: Narrowing of the spinal canal in the lower portion of the spine (known as the lumbar spine).

lutein.des_en: A natural substance found in green leafy vegetables.

luteinizing hormone.des_en: A hormone that controls ovulation in women. In men, luteinizing hormone triggers production of testosterone.

luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone ag.des_en: A drug that slows the production of hormones by the testicles in men or the ovaries in women.

LVAD.des_en: Abbreviation for left-ventricular assist device, a surgically implanted pump that augments the pumping action of the left ventricle.

Lyme disease.des_en: An infectious disease transmitted by a tick bite.

lymph nodes.des_en: Small, bean-shaped organs that filter germs and foreign matter out of the body. Also called lymph glands.

lymphatic system.des_en: A system of channels that drains excess clear fluid, called lymph, from tissues and returns it into the bloodstream.

macrocytic anemia.des_en: The presence of larger-than-normal red blood cells in circulation—even though there are too few of them—caused by lack of folate and vitamin B12.

macular degeneration.des_en: An eye disease that slowly destroys sharp, clear central vision.

macular edema.des_en: The build-up of fluid in the macula caused by fluid leaking from blood vessels in the eye. It can blur and damage vision.

Magenblase syndrome.des_en: Swallowing too much air during a meal, causing excessive gas and discomfort. Also known as stomach bubble syndrome.

magnetic resonance imaging.des_en: A scan that creates detailed pictures of internal organs; commonly referred to as MRI. Magnetic resonance imaging uses radio waves, a strong magnetic field, and a computer to produce images of organs and internal tissues.

maintenance of wakefulness test.des_en: A test to measure sleepiness during the day. A tester measures how long it takes a person who is sitting up in a chair or bed to fall asleep after he or she has been asked to stay awake.

major depression.des_en: Depression that interferes with daily life for an extended period. Episodes of major depression during bereavement can be distinguished from normal sadness by such symptoms as persistent feelings of worthlessness, thoughts about death, feelings of guilt, persistent trouble functioning, and marked mental and physical sluggishness.

major histocompatibility complex molecul.des_en: Molecules that help protect the body from foreign substances. These molecules display proteins on the surface of cells so that protective immune system cells can kill the protein if it is harmful to the body.

maladaptive stress response.des_en: An unhealthy physiological response to stressors, in which the stress response often does not turn off even when the stressor disappears.

malignant hypertension.des_en: A dangerous type of high blood pressure marked by an unusually sudden rise in blood pressure to very high levels, often accompanied by headache, blurred vision, and seizures.

MAOIs.des_en: Abbreviation for monoamine oxidase inhibitors, medications used to treat depression. They work by making the chemical messengers serotonin and norepinephrine more available.

mastoid bone.des_en: The bone in the skull behind the ear.

mastopexy.des_en: A cosmetic surgery to reshape and lift drooping breasts. Commonly known as a breast lift.

maximizer.des_en: A person who typically evaluates all options before making a decision, in an effort to identify the perfect choice, and who never settles for second-best.

meal plan.des_en: A detailed guide outlining the amounts and types of food a person should eat each day.

Medicaid.des_en: A government program that offers health care for low-income Americans of any age.

Medicare.des_en: A government program that offers health care for Americans ages 65 and older.

Medigap insurance.des_en: Health insurance policies that fill in the holes in Medicare coverage.

megaloblastic anemia.des_en: Fewer than normal healthy red blood cells in circulation, caused by a lack of folate or vitamin B12. Red cells become large and deformed, and are unable to carry oxygen efficiently.

meglitinides.des_en: A type of medication taken to treat type 2 diabetes.

melanocytes.des_en: Cells located deep in the epidermis that produce melanin, the pigment that colors skin.

melatonin.des_en: A hormone that regulates the body’s sleep-wake cycle.

memory T cells and B cells.des_en: Immune cells that remember harmful agents that have entered the body in the past. When they spot the substance again, they spur the immune system to eliminate the invader.

metabolic equivalents.des_en: Units used to estimate the oxygen consumption, or metabolic cost, of physical activity, and, hence, its intensity. One metabolic equivalent (MET) is the estimated energy cost of the body at rest.

metabolic syndrome.des_en: A cluster of risk factors that accelerate the progression of heart disease.

metered-dose inhaler.des_en: A device that delivers a specific dose of an inhaled asthma medication.

Methanobrevibacter smithii.des_en: Bacteria in the gut that help with the digestion of complex sugars.

METs.des_en: Abbreviation for metabolic equivalents, units used to estimate the oxygen consumption, or metabolic cost, of physical activity, and, hence, its intensity. One MET is the estimated energy cost of the body at rest.

MHC molecule.des_en: Abbreviation for major histocompatibility complex molecule, molecules that help protect the body from foreign substances. These molecules display proteins on the surface of cells so that protective immune system cells can kill the protein if it is harmful to the body.

microalbuminuria.des_en: Leakage of small amounts of a protein called albumin into the urine caused by kidney disease or damage.

microaneurysm.des_en: A tiny bulge that develops in the wall of a blood vessel.

microdermabrasion.des_en: A cosmetic procedure in which tiny crystals under high pressure are sprayed on the face. This buffs away the outer layer of skin, eliminates fine lines, and improves the look of the skin.

micronized.des_en: Reducing a substance to very small particles.

microvascular disease.des_en: A condition in which the smallest blood vessels in the walls of the heart are narrowed or inelastic.

micturition.des_en: Emptying the bladder. Also called urination or voiding.

migraine headache.des_en: A severe headache with pain that usually begins on one side of the head. Symptoms may include visual disturbances (called aura), nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light or noise.

migraine with aura.des_en: A severe headache preceded by visual disturbances such as flashing lights, seeing lines, or a blind spot.

migraine without aura.des_en: A severe headache that is not preceded by visual disturbances such as flashing lights. Also known as common migraine.

mild cognitive impairment.des_en: The loss of some brain functions, such as memory, thinking, or language, that is noticeable, but doesn’t interfere with ability to carry out daily tasks.

milligram.des_en: A metric unit of weight equivalent to one-thousandth of a gram. Abbreviated as mg.

mindfulness.des_en: A practice with its roots in Buddhism that encourages people to be more fully aware of the present moment. Often achieved through meditation.

mindfulness meditation.des_en: A form of meditation with roots in ancient Buddhist practice through which a person has a calm awareness of his or her body and feelings and is fully engaged in the present; also called insight meditation.

mindfulness-based cognitive behavioral t.des_en: A well-established acceptance-based therapy, used principally in treatment of depression and anxiety.

mindlessness.des_en: Acting without full attention to one's surroundings, behavior, or internal experience.

mitochondria.des_en: Small structures within cells that create break down nutrients and create energy for cells. Known as the power producers or energy factories of cells.

mitral valve stenosis.des_en: A narrowing of the mitral valve opening that limits blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle.

monoamine oxidase inhibitors.des_en: Medications used to treat depression. They work by making the chemical messengers serotonin and norepinephrine more available.

monoclonal antibody.des_en: An antibody is a protein molecule that can bind to a virus and mark it for destruction by the immune system. A monoclonal antibody is a man-made substance used to treat some viral and other diseases.

monocytes.des_en: White blood cells that protect the body from disease by attacking and consuming foreign particles.

monounsaturated fat.des_en: A type of fat abundant in vegetable oils such as olive, peanut, sesame, and canola oils. Monounsaturated fats don’t raise levels of unhealthy LDL cholesterol, and may even lower it.

Morton’s neuroma.des_en: A thickening of nerve tissue between the toes that causes irritation, tingling, or a burning pain in the ball of the foot.

motilin.des_en: A hormone that helps the small intestine contract and move food through the digestive tract.

motor neuron.des_en: A nerve cell that directs activity in a specific group of muscle fibers.

mucous cysts.des_en: Small cysts that form between the nail bed and the top joint of the finger.

multi-infarct dementia.des_en: Memory loss and impaired thinking caused by tiny strokes that are often too small to notice until a sizable area of the brain is affected.

multinodular goiter.des_en: An enlargement of the thyroid gland with more than one lump or nodule appearing on the neck.

multiple sleep latency test.des_en: A sleep test to measure daytime sleepiness. It times how quickly a person falls asleep when asked to rest in a quiet, darkened room during the day.

muscle fatigue.des_en: Weakness felt in muscles when they have been tired out.

muscle fibers.des_en: Cells bundled together to make up muscle tissue. Also known as muscle cells.

muscle-contraction headache.des_en: A headache characterized by constant pressure, mild to moderate pain, and the feeling that a tight band is squeezing the head. Also known as a tension headache.

muscular endurance.des_en: The ability of muscle to continue to perform without stopping because of fatigue.

muscularis.des_en: The thin layer of smooth muscle lining of the colon or rectum.

musculoskeletal.des_en: Related to the muscles and the skeleton.

MUSE.des_en: Abbreviation for medicated urethral system for erection. In this therapy, a small drug pellet is inserted into the tip of the penis to produce an erection.

myocardial rupture.des_en: Tearing of one of the walls of the heart. It usually occurs immediately after a heart attack.

myofibrils.des_en: Long interlocking strands that make up muscle fibers.

myofilaments.des_en: The fundamental muscle proteins that form myofibrils. Myofilaments slide over one another, bunching up and generating force, when a muscle contracts.

myosin.des_en: A protein that helps muscle contract and relax.

nanograms per milliliter.des_en: A small quantity of a substance; equivalent to one-billionth of a gram (454 grams make 1 pound) in one-thousandth of a liter (1 liter is approximately 1 quart). Abbreviated as ng/ml.

nasolabial folds.des_en: Lines in the skin leading from the nose to the outer corners of the mouth. Also known as smile or laugh lines.

natural killer cells.des_en: A type of white blood cell of the immune system. These cells destroy other cells that fail to display the right chemical flags signaling that they are normal cells.

natural recoverers.des_en: People who overcome addiction without treatment or formal self-help programs.

needle biopsy.des_en: Use of a hollow needle to remove a small sample of tissue for examination.

neoadjuvant therapy.des_en: A helper treatment given before a primary treatment is started, such as when chemotherapy is done before surgery in order to shrink a tumor.

neoplasm.des_en: An abnormal growth of tissue, either cancerous or benign.

nerve block.des_en: Injection of a medication into one or more nerves to relieve pain.

nerve growth factor.des_en: A molecule in the body that promotes the growth and repair of nerve cells.

nerve sparing.des_en: When referring to prostatectomy, the surgical procedure that preserves the nerves needed to allow the penis to become erect.

neuritic plaques.des_en: Clumps of sticky proteins found in the brains of people with Alzheimer's disease.

neurofibrillary tangles.des_en: Twisted strands of proteins that are found inside the dead or dying nerve cells of people with Alzheimer's disease.

neuroleptic agents.des_en: Powerful tranquilizing drugs used to treat schizophrenia.

neuromuscular junction.des_en: The tiny space between the end of a nerve and the surface of a muscle.

neuropeptides.des_en: Small proteins that aid in transmitting signals between nerve cells.

neurotransmitter receptors.des_en: Cell structures (usually proteins) that recognize specific neurotransmitters and bind to them. Once bound, a receptor often changes shape, causing a cascade of chemical events within the cell. These events can alter which genes are turned on or off and can make the cell more or less likely to release its neurotransmitters.

neutral alignment.des_en: Keeping the body in a straight line from head to toe except for the slight natural curves of the spine.

neutral posture.des_en: A standing or seated position in which the chin is parallel to the floor; the shoulders, hips, and knees are at even heights; and the knees and feet point straight ahead.

neutral spine.des_en: A position in which the back is straight except for the slight natural curves of the spine.

neutropenia.des_en: An abnormally low number of white blood cells.

neutrophils.des_en: White blood cells that seek out and engulf foreign cells.

nitrates.des_en: Medications that widen blood vessels; usually used to treat chest pain from angina and other heart problems.

nitric oxide.des_en: A compound produced by the endothelium (the lining of the interior walls of arteries) that helps widen blood vessels and counteract high blood pressure. Also called endothelium-derived relaxing factor.

nitroglycerin.des_en: A drug that relaxes blood vessels and increases the supply of blood and oxygen to the heart while reducing its workload. It is commonly used to treat angina.

NK.des_en: Abbreviation for natural killer cells, a type of white blood cell of the immune system. These cells destroy other cells that fail to display the right chemical flags signaling that they are normal cells.

NMDA receptor.des_en: Abbreviation for the N-methyl-D-aspartame receptor, a molecule on the surface of a brain cell that admits calcium when activated by the chemical messenger glutamate.

N-methyl-D-aspartame receptor.des_en: A molecule on the surface of a brain cell that admits calcium when activated by the chemical messenger glutamate.

NO.des_en: Abbreviation for nitric oxide, a compound produced by the endothelium (the lining of the interior walls of arteries) that helps widen blood vessels and counteract high blood pressure. Also called endothelium-derived relaxing factor.

nociceptors.des_en: Nerve endings that detect pain and transmit pain information to the brain and spinal cord.

nodule.des_en: A small rounded bump or knot of tissue.

nomogram.des_en: A chart or graph of mathematical calculations of risk; used in making treatment recommendations and predicting outcomes.

non-HDL cholesterol.des_en: The sum of all cholesterol types other than high-density lipoprotein (HDL). These include very-low-density lipoprotein, low-density lipoprotein, and intermediate-density lipoprotein.

non-insulin-dependent diabetes.des_en: Now called type 2 diabetes. A disease in which levels of blood sugar (glucose) are too high initially because cells can’t properly use insulin (a hormone that helps cells absorb glucose from the bloodstream). Over time the production of insulin may decline.

noninvasive test.des_en: A test that does not require any medical instruments to break the skin or enter the body.

nonketotic hyperglycemic hyperosmolar sy.des_en: A rare and very serious condition associated with type 2 diabetes. Symptoms include extremely high (more than 800 mg/dl) blood sugar levels, severe dehydration, and changes in mental status, ultimately resulting in coma.

nonproliferative retinopathy.des_en: A condition in which the walls of the small blood vessels in the retina leak serum and tiny pockets of swelling form in the walls of blood vessels. Also called background retinopathy.

non-REM sleep.des_en: The sleep phase that includes deep sleep, the type considered most important for preventing daytime sleepiness.

nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.des_en: A drug that reduces swelling and pain.

norepinephrine.des_en: A hormone produced by adrenal glands that puts the body on heightened alert when a threat is perceived (the fight-or-flight response). Also known as noradrenaline.

NSAID.des_en: Abbreviation for nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, a drug that reduce swelling and pain.

nuclear tests.des_en: Tests that use tiny amounts of short-lived radioactive substances that can target particular organs or cell receptors to diagnose disease.

nucleus accumbens.des_en: Part of the brain’s reward pathway that is most tightly and consistently responsive to pleasure. Also known as the pleasure center.

nucleus pulposus.des_en: The gel-like shock-absorbing central portion of each spinal disc.

nutraceutical.des_en: Dietary supplement containing concentrated forms of a presumed bioactive substance originally derived from food and used to enhance health in dosages exceeding those normally obtainable from food.

object of addiction.des_en: The psychoactive drug or rewarding behavior with which a person with addiction has a pathological relationship.

occipital lobe.des_en: The region in the back of the brain responsible for visual processing.

occult.des_en: Something not visible to the naked eye but seen under a microscope or through lab tests.

omega-3 fatty acids.des_en: Beneficial fats, also known as n-3 fatty acids. These are polyunsaturated fat found in fatty fish, such as salmon.

omega-6 fatty acids.des_en: Fatty acids found in certain foods that the body needs for good health but can’t make on its own. Also known as n-6 fatty acids.

oncologist.des_en: A physician who deals with the diagnosis and treatment of cancer. There are three types—medical oncologists, radiation oncologists, and surgical oncologists.

Ondine's curse.des_en: A rare and potentially fatal disorder in which a person may stop breathing, especially at night. Also called congenital central hypoventilation syndrome.

open prostatectomy.des_en: A surgical procedure in which an enlarged prostate is removed through an incision in the abdomen.

opioid.des_en: Any narcotic, natural or synthetic, that behaves in the body like an opium-derived drug.

optic disk.des_en: The front surface of the optic nerve, where all the retinal nerve fibers come together to carry an image to the brain.

optic nerve.des_en: A cable of specialized nerve fibers that transmit visual impulses from the eye to the brain.

optimism.des_en: A characteristic frame of mind that leads a person to expect positive outcomes and to view the world as a positive place.

optometrist.des_en: A health care professional licensed to examine the eye, and diagnose and treat some eye diseases.

oral glucose tolerance test.des_en: A test to check for diabetes. It involves fasting overnight and having blood sugar levels checked before and after drinking a sugary solution.

oral mucosa.des_en: The layer of soft pinkish tissue that lines the interior of the mouth.

orbit.des_en: The bony socket that holds the eyeball.

orbital irradiation.des_en: X-ray treatment to the eye; sometimes used in more serious cases of Graves’ eye disease.

orchiectomy.des_en: Surgery to remove the testicles. Usually done to remove a cancerous testicle or to lower testosterone levels and slow or halt the growth of prostate cancer.

organic matrix.des_en: The protein framework of bone tissue.

organonitrile.des_en: A chemical found in cruciferous vegetables that may have anti-cancer properties.

orthostatic hypotension.des_en: A sudden drop in blood pressure upon standing or getting out of bed, causing dizziness.

osseointegration.des_en: A process in which bone heals around an implant to create a stable anchor.

ossicles.des_en: Three bones in the middle ear that move in response to sound vibrations.

osteocytes.des_en: A cell that is embedded in fully formed bone.

osteons.des_en: The building blocks of compact bone, the hard, tightly-packed tissue that forms the outer shell of bones.

otic capsule.des_en: The bony shell that surrounds the inner ear.

outbreak.des_en: Synonymous with epidemic. Sometimes used to refer to a local epidemic as compared to a larger, general epidemic.

outpatient.des_en: A person who receives treatment at a hospital or other medical facility but does not stay overnight.

output.des_en: The loudest sound that a hearing aid can produce.

overactive bladder.des_en: Frequent urination and urges to urinate.

overt proteinuria.des_en: A condition of declining kidney function. It is part of the progression of kidney disease, developing after microalbuminuria (when a damaged kidney begins to leak small amounts of a protein called albumin into urine) and before chronic kidney disease.

oxygenated blood.des_en: Blood that has moved through the lungs where it has absorbed oxygen; oxygenated blood moves from the lungs into the heart, from which it is then pumped throughout the body.

pacemaker, artificial.des_en: A small electronic device generally placed in the chest to correct an irregular heartbeat. It generates small electrical pulses that prompt the heart to beat at a normal pace.

pacemaker, natural.des_en: A specialized cluster of cells called the sinoatrial node in the top of the right atrium. The pacemaker produces a steady flow of beat now signals that flash across the atria and then pass through the atrioventricular node to the ventricles.

PAD.des_en: Abbreviation for peripheral artery disease, a condition caused by atherosclerosis in the arteries in the legs or leading to them.

palliative care.des_en: Treatment that relieves the symptoms of a serious illness, but does not cure the disease itself.

palsy.des_en: Paralysis in part of the body, often with loss of sensation and uncontrolled body movements.

pannus.des_en: An abnormal layer of tissue that forms over joints or the cornea of the eye.

papillary muscles.des_en: Threads of muscle that pull the heart valves between the upper and lower chambers of the heart closed during heart contractions.

parasomnias.des_en: Sleep disorders, such as night terrors or sleep walking, that periodically interfere with sleep.

parathyroid glands.des_en: Glands responsible for releasing a hormone that controls calcium levels and influences bone loss and growth.

parietal lobe.des_en: Part of the brain. It plays a role in sensory processes, like pain and touch, and language.

paroxysmal hemicrania.des_en: A rare form of headache. Sufferers experience a severe throbbing, drilling pain on one side of the face or behind the eye.

passive immunity.des_en: Immunity that is conferred by another, such as a mother’s antibodies protecting her baby during gestation and shortly after birth.

patch test.des_en: A test used to diagnose whether a rash was caused by a reaction to certain allergens, such as poison ivy or a cosmetic ingredient, or an irritant such as soap.

patient-controlled analgesia.des_en: A method that allows a person to control, within limits, the amount and timing of pain medication he or she receives. It is usually done by pressing a button to release the medication from a computerized pump into an IV.

pattern-recognition receptors.des_en: Proteins that recognize classes of pathogens and stimulate the innate immune system to signal the adaptive immune system.

PCOS.des_en: Abbreviation for polycystic ovary syndrome, an inherited disorder characterized by the formation of abnormal cysts in enlarged ovaries; a leading cause of female infertility and a common cause of excess facial or body hair (hirsutism).

PDE5 inhibitors.des_en: Abbreviation for phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors, drugs that can help a man achieve and maintain an erection.

peak bone mass.des_en: The greatest amount of bone tissue that a person has during his or her life.

peak flow.des_en: A measure of how fast a person can blow air out of the lungs.

peak flow meter.des_en: A device to assess lung function, often used to diagnose and monitor asthma.

Pediculus humanus capitis.des_en: A blood-sucking parasite commonly known as the louse (plural, lice) that can cause an itchy scalp; infestations are highly contagious and especially common in school-age children.

penile prosthesis.des_en: An inflatable or bendable device that is implanted in the penis to allow a man with erectile dysfunction to have erections when he wishes.

percutaneous diskectomy.des_en: Surgical removal of part of a spinal disk that is bulging out abnormally and pressing on a nerve root or the spinal column.

percutaneous electrical nerve stimulatio.des_en: A pain relief therapy that uses needles to deliver low-voltage electrical current under the skin to stop pain signals from reaching the brain.

percutaneous transluminal coronary angio.des_en: A procedure used to open blocked coronary arteries. A small, thin tube with a tiny balloon at its tip is inserted into a narrowed coronary artery. The balloon is then inflated to widen the narrowed area. A stent may be put in place to hold the artery open. Percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty is also known as balloon angioplasty.

performance anxiety.des_en: Concern about sexual performance that is so severe that it leads to sexual dysfunction.

perfusion defect.des_en: A test result that indicates abnormal blood flow or areas of damaged or dead heart muscle.

perimenopause.des_en: The transition time in a woman’s life that begins when ovaries produce less estrogen and menstruation becomes less frequent, and ends when the ovaries no longer produce eggs and menstruation stops.

periodic limb movement disorder.des_en: A sleep disorder in which the legs jerk or cramp repeatedly during the sleep.

periodization.des_en: An exercise strategy that varies reps, sets, and resistance to alternate heavier and lighter workouts over a period of time.

periodontal disease.des_en: Diseases, including gingivitis and periodontitis, that attack the gum tissue and the structures supporting the teeth. Also called gum disease.

periodontitis.des_en: An advanced stage of gum disease that attacks the teeth’s supporting structures.

peripheral artery disease.des_en: A condition caused by atherosclerosis in the arteries in the legs or leading to them.

peripheral nervous system.des_en: The parts of the nervous system outside of the brain, brain stem, and spinal cord.

peripheral neuropathy.des_en: Damage to the long nerves radiating from the spine to the arms and legs.

peripheral vascular disease.des_en: Narrowing of blood vessels that supply blood to the legs, arms, stomach, or kidneys.

peripheral vision.des_en: Side vision, or what the eye perceives outside the direct line of vision.

peritoneal dialysis.des_en: Treatment for kidney failure that uses a machine to remove toxins from the bloodstream.

personal emergency response system.des_en: A device worn around the neck or wrist that allows a person to call for help by pressing a button.

pessary.des_en: A device placed in the vagina to support or correct the position of the uterus, rectum, or bladder.

PET scan.des_en: Abbreviation for positron emission tomography, a medical imaging test that uses a radioactive substance to assess organ and tissue function in the body and to look for disease.

Peyronie’s disease.des_en: Scarring of some of the tissue inside the penis, causing the penis to bend at an angle during an erection.

pH monitoring.des_en: A test to determine whether stomach acid is backing up into the esophagus. For this test, a sensing probe is inserted through the nose and positioned above the lower esophageal sphincter.

phacoemulsification.des_en: A method of cataract removal. It uses ultrasound waves to break up the clouded lens of the eye so it can be suctioned out with a needle.

phase shift disorder.des_en: Sleep problem that results when a person's internal clock becomes out of sync with external time. This can be a problem for people who work the night shift.

phase-2 enzyme.des_en: A helpful enzyme that seems to clear toxins and help prevent cancer-causing substances from binding to DNA.

phenothiazines.des_en: Powerful tranquilizing drugs used to treat schizophrenia and, sometimes, severe nausea.

phenylpropanolamine.des_en: A decongestant drug used to treat nasal congestion and sometimes mild incontinence.

phonophobia.des_en: Sensitivity to noise, often experienced during a migraine attack.

phosphodiesterase type 5.des_en: An enzyme that breaks down substances that help the penis become erect and maintain an erection.

photocoagulation.des_en: Use of a laser to seal off blood vessels.

photodynamic therapy.des_en: A medical treatment that uses a light source to activate a photosensitizing drug (one that becomes activated by light exposure). Often used in oncology, dermatology, and cosmetic surgery.

photophobia.des_en: Sensitivity to light, often experienced during a migraine attack.

photopsia.des_en: A sensation of sparks or flashes of light across the visual field.

photorefractive keratectomy.des_en: Laser surgery used to reshape the cornea in order to correct vision problems.

photorejuvenation.des_en: A cosmetic procedure that uses intense pulsed light to remove wrinkles and improve skin tone and texture.

physiatrist.des_en: A physician who specializes in physical medicine, pain, and rehabilitation. These doctors diagnose and treat sports injuries and degenerative conditions like arthritis or low back pain, and oversee rehab for patients with severe impairments resulting from trauma, stroke, and other conditions.

physical activity.des_en: Any voluntary body movements that burn calories, including walking up stairs, vacuuming a floor, going for a brisk stroll, or engaging in a structured program of exercise.

physical dependence.des_en: The process through which the body becomes accustomed to a psychoactive drug or rewarding behavior and misses it if it’s taken away. People with physical dependence who stop or cut down on their substance or activity of choice might develop uncomfortable withdrawal symptoms.

physical fitness.des_en: A state of being physically sound and healthy; having the ability to perform physical activity well.

phytochemicals.des_en: Substances made by plants that have biological effects in the human body. Examples include isoflavones, lycopene, lutein, and zeaxanthin.

phytoestrogen.des_en: A plant component that mimics the effects of estrogen hormones in the body.

Pick's disease.des_en: A brain disorder that causes dementia, neurotic behavior, and gradual changes in personality and emotional control.

pineal gland.des_en: A gland located in the middle of the brain, between the brain’s two hemispheres, that produces melatonin in response to declining light.

Pittsburgh Compound B.des_en: A substance that binds to amyloid proteins in the brain (markers for Alzheimer’s disease), making them visible under positron emission tomography (PET) scanning.

pituitary gland.des_en: The so-called master gland, located at the base of the brain. It controls and regulates the thyroid and other glands throughout the endocrine system.

placebo effect.des_en: A change or improvement in symptoms that is due to a dummy medication or treatment (placebo) rather than a real drug or treatment.

plantar fascia.des_en: Connective tissue in the foot which joins the heel bone to the ball of the foot.

plantar fasciitis.des_en: An inflammation of the plantar fascia; the leading cause of heel pain.

plantar wart.des_en: A wart on the sole of the foot, caused by a virus.

plasma cells.des_en: White blood cells that produce large quantities of antibodies as part of an immune system response.

plasmin.des_en: An enzyme that breaks down the protein involved in clotting blood (fibrin), dissolving the clot.

poliosis.des_en: A localized patch of gray or white hair on the scalp, eyebrows, or eyelashes.

polycystic ovary syndrome.des_en: An inherited disorder characterized by the formation of abnormal cysts in enlarged ovaries; a leading cause of female infertility and a common cause of hirsutism.

polyp.des_en: An abnormal, noncancerous growth that protrudes from mucous membranes, like those found in the sinuses and colon lining.

polysomnography.des_en: A sleep study that examines brain waves and other measures of physiological functioning.

polyunsaturated fat.des_en: A type of fat that is abundant in soybean, corn, cottonseed, safflower, and sunflower oils, as well as in fatty fish. One type, omega-3 fats, are especially important for cardiovascular health.

positive psychology.des_en: A branch of psychology that studies mental health rather than illness, focusing on how life can be more happy and fulfilling.

positron emission tomography.des_en: A medical imaging test that uses a radioactive substance to assess organ and tissue function in the body and to look for disease. Commonly called a PET scan.

posterior chamber.des_en: The part of the eye behind the iris and in front of the lens that is filled with aqueous humor.

posterior heel bursitis.des_en: An inflammation of the bursa sac surrounding the joint in the heel of the foot, causing swelling and pain.

posterior keyhole foraminotomy.des_en: A minimally invasive surgical procedure that is sometimes an option for repairing a herniated disk.

posterior myocardial infarction.des_en: Heart attack involving the rear wall of the heart muscle.

postherpetic neuralgia.des_en: Nerve pain caused by the herpes zoster virus, also known as shingles.

postmenopausal osteoporosis.des_en: Bone loss caused by lower estrogen levels associated with menopause. Sometimes called type I osteoporosis.

postmenopause.des_en: The period in a woman's life lasting from the end of perimenopause until the end of life.

post-traumatic headache.des_en: A persistent headache resulting from a head or neck injury, sometimes lasting for a year or more.

post-traumatic stress disorder.des_en: A prolonged reaction to a traumatic event. Post-traumatic stress disorder can cause crippling anxiety and leading to other problems, such as sleep disturbances, depression, and substance abuse. Often referred to as PTSD.

post-void residual.des_en: The amount of urine left in the bladder after urinating.

power.des_en: Force times speed of movement. It reflects how quickly a given force is exerted.

power training.des_en: An emerging field of physical medicine aimed at boosting the ability to exert strength quickly, especially in relation to practical, day-to-day tasks.

prazosin.des_en: A member of a class of drugs called alpha blockers. Prazosin eases the symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia by relaxing smooth muscle tissue in the capsule that surrounds the prostate.

prediabetes.des_en: A fasting blood sugar level above a healthy level, but still below the level used to diagnose diabetes. An individual with prediabetes is at increased risk for developing diabetes.

prehypertension.des_en: Blood pressure that is above normal but not high enough to qualify as hypertension. An individual with prehypertension is at increased risk for developing hypertension.

preload reduction.des_en: A method of reducing cardiac workload by decreasing the pressure of blood entering the heart.

premature atrial contraction.des_en: An early beat in an atria that feels like the heart skipped a beat.

premature ejaculation.des_en: Ejaculation that occurs before or immediately after penetration; this can interfere with a couple having a mutually satisfying sexual experience.

premature ventricular contraction.des_en: An early beat in a ventricle that feels like the heart skipped a beat.

presbycusis.des_en: Age-related hearing loss caused by the death of hair cells in the inner ear.

prick test.des_en: A commonly used skin test to confirm hypersensitivity to a broad range of allergens.

primary angioplasty.des_en: Use of angioplasty as the first treatment to open a blocked artery that is causing a heart attack, rather than using clot-busting (thrombolytic) drugs.

primary hypertension.des_en: High blood pressure with no known cause. Also known as essential hypertension.

primary osteoporosis.des_en: Bone loss that results from a normal physiological process, such as menopause or aging.

probate.des_en: A public, legal process supervised by the courts after a person dies that helps ensure debts are paid and assets are properly owned and correctly distributed.

probiotic.des_en: Live microorganisms used to benefit health, such as the L. acidophilus bacteria found in yogurt.

procedural memory.des_en: The long-term memory of skills and procedures, or how-to knowledge. Also called implicit memory.

processes.des_en: Bony projections that extend in several directions from each vertebra bone in the spine.

progestin.des_en: A synthetic compound that produces effects similar to those of the hormone progesterone.

progressive muscle relaxation.des_en: A mind/body technique for inducing the relaxation response that involves isolating, tensing, and relaxing specific sets of muscles in sequence.

prolapsed disk.des_en: When part of a spinal disk bulges out of a tear or weak spot in the disk’s tough outer shell. Also known as herniated disk.

proliferative retinopathy.des_en: An advanced stage of diabetic eye disease characterized by the development of new blood vessels that grow into the vitreous cavity; they are fragile and may bleed and cause loss of vision.

proprioception.des_en: The ability to sense the position of one’s body in space, in relation to other objects.

prospective study.des_en: A type of research method that collects data on a group of people at the start of the study and then follows them into the future, gathering data over time.

prostaglandins.des_en: A group of chemicals that have hormone-like actions; prostaglandins help regulate blood pressure and contraction of smooth-muscle cells (for example, those in the lining of the blood vessels).

prostate-specific antigen.des_en: A protein produced by the prostate. Elevated levels may indicate the presence of cancer, benign prostatic hyperplasia, or prostatitis. Often referred to as PSA.

prostatic urethral stent.des_en: A small, springlike cylinder, designed to relieve pressure from an enlarged prostate and improve urine flow by widening a narrowed urethra.

protease inhibitor.des_en: A class of drugs that help fight retrovirus infections; commonly prescribed to treat human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

protocol.des_en: A plan that lays out the procedures that will be followed in conducting a physical examination, a research study, or the treatment of a disease.

PSA.des_en: Abbreviation for prostate-specific antigen, a protein produced by the prostate. Elevated levels may indicate the presence of cancer, benign prostatic hyperplasia, or prostatitis.

PSA velocity.des_en: The rate at which a man’s PSA level increases over time.

pseudoephedrine.des_en: A decongestant drug that may also relieve mild incontinence.

pseudogout.des_en: Arthritis caused by crystals of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate in the joints. Also known as calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate disease.

psychodynamic therapy.des_en: A form of therapy that focuses on how life events, desires, and close relationships lead to conflict, symptoms such as anxiety or depression, and difficulty in managing life’s tasks.

psychogenic erectile dysfunction.des_en: Difficulty in getting or maintaining erections because of a psychological cause, such as stress or depression.

PTCA.des_en: Abbreviation for percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty, a procedure used to open blocked coronary arteries.

PTSD.des_en: Abbreviation for post-traumatic stress disorder, a prolonged reaction to a traumatic event. PTSD can cause crippling anxiety and leading to other problems, such as sleep disturbances, depression, and substance abuse.

puborectalis muscle.des_en: A pelvic floor muscle that forms a sling around the rectum and helps maintain fecal continence.

pudendal arteries.des_en: Arteries supplying blood to the genital area.

pudendal nerve.des_en: The nerve that carries sensation from the genital area to the central nervous system.

pulmonary veins.des_en: The veins that carry blood from the lungs to the left atrium.

pulp.des_en: Tissue containing nerves and blood vessels that fills the chamber at the center of the tooth.

pulse pressure.des_en: The difference between systolic blood pressure and diastolic blood pressure (systolic pressure minus diastolic pressure = pulse pressure). Pulse pressure may help predict heart disease risk.

pump failure.des_en: When the heart muscle becomes so weak that it can no longer pump enough blood to the rest of the body.

pupil.des_en: The dark, circular opening in the middle of the iris of the eye.

pyloric sphincter.des_en: A muscular valve at the lower end of the stomach that opens to the duodenum.

quantitative computed tomography.des_en: A modification of computed tomography that provides measurements of bone mass as well as an image.

quick relievers.des_en: Medications that quickly open the bronchial tubes by relaxing the muscles surrounding these airways.

quiet sleep.des_en: Any sleep other than REM sleep, in which thinking and most physiological activities slow, but movement still occurs. Also called non-REM sleep.

radial tunnel syndrome.des_en: A condition in which the radial nerve is compressed at the elbow, causing pain, numbness, tingling, and muscle weakness in the hand and arm.

radical prostatectomy.des_en: Surgery to remove the entire prostate.

radioactive iodine.des_en: A radioactive form of iodine that can be used as a tracer during a radioactive iodine uptake test or a radioactive thyroid scan. Much larger amounts are used in the treatment of hyperthyroidism.

radioallergosorbent test.des_en: A blood test used for identifying allergens.

radiofrequency.des_en: A non-surgical technique using an electromagnetic current to penetrate deep into the body’s tissues, which can be used to treat pain, cancer, and heart rhythm disorders, among other conditions.

radionuclides.des_en: Short-lived radioactive chemicals that are used in nuclear imaging tests.

rales.des_en: Abnormal lung sounds that might be a sign of fluid buildup congestion in the lungs.

randomized.des_en: A feature of many clinical trials in which participants are randomly assigned to either a group to be tested or a control group.

randomized controlled trial.des_en: A study in which researchers choose a study population at random; one group receives the intervention (such as a nutritional supplement) and another group receives a placebo. Often referred to as an RCT.

range of motion.des_en: The extent of movement—and thus flexibility—in a joint, measured in the degrees of a circle.

rapid eye movement sleep.des_en: A period of intense brain activity during sleep, often associated with dreams; named for the rapid eye movements that occur during this time. Also called dreaming sleep.

RAST.des_en: Abbreviation for radioallergosorbent test, a blood test used for identifying allergens.

RCT.des_en: Abbreviation for randomized controlled trial, a study in which researchers choose a study population at random; one group receives the intervention (such as a nutritional supplement) and another group receives a placebo.

RDA.des_en: Abbreviation for recommended dietary allowance, the average daily amount of a nutrient that will meet the nutritional needs of almost all (97%–98%) healthy people at specific stages of their lives.

reactive arthritis.des_en: Joint problems triggered by bacterial or viral infection elsewhere in the body.

rebound insomnia.des_en: Insomnia caused by withdrawal from sleep medication; usually it is at least as serious as before the medication was used.

receptors.des_en: Structures on the outside of a cell membrane that permit attachment of specific chemicals.

recombinant tissue plasminogen activator.des_en: A thrombolytic (clot-dissolving) drug made using recombinant DNA technology; used to dissolve blood clots causing an ischemic stroke, pulmonary embolism, or myocardial infarction.

recommended dietary allowance.des_en: The average daily amount of a nutrient that will meet the nutritional needs of almost all (97%–98%) healthy people at specific stages of their lives.

rehabilitative driving specialist.des_en: A professional trained to evaluate driving skills and, when appropriate, suggest equipment and adaptations to make driving safer for people with certain physical or mental limitations.

relaxation response.des_en: The physical effects of meditation and certain other techniques that are opposite to those of the stress response. Effects include marked drops in oxygen consumption, carbon dioxide expiration, heartbeat, and respiration, as well as stabilization or lowering of blood pressure.

REM.des_en: Abbreviation for rapid eye movement, which occurs during a period of sleep characterized by intense brain activity, often associated with dreams.

REM behavior disorder.des_en: A sleep disorder marked by movement during REM sleep, when muscles are normally paralyzed.

REM rebound.des_en: An increase in REM sleep, often with nightmares, that occurs after deprivation of REM sleep or the withdrawal of REM-suppressing medications.

remodeling.des_en: Altering a body part. Bone is constantly being remodeled in response to exercise or inactivity. Heart tissue is remodeled in response to a heart attack or high blood pressure.

renal artery stenosis.des_en: Narrowing of an artery that supplies blood to the kidney.

reperfusion.des_en: Re-establishing blood flow, such as when a blockage in a coronary artery that is causing a heart attack is cleared.

reperfusion therapy.des_en: Techniques used to restart circulation to part of the heart or brain that has been cut off from blood flow during a heart attack or stroke. Reperfusion may entail clot-dissolving drugs, balloon angioplasty, or surgery.

repetitions.des_en: Number of times an exercise calls for a muscle to be worked and released (usually eight to 12). Often referred to as reps.

resectoscope.des_en: An instrument that permits a surgeon to view the inside of a body cavity in order to remove a part of an organ or structure.

resilience.des_en: The ability to adapt to change and recover quickly from setbacks such as illness, injury, or misfortune.

resistant hypertension.des_en: High blood pressure that does not respond to drug therapy and lifestyle changes.

restenosis.des_en: Renarrowing of a blood vessel that has been widened with angioplasty.

resting energy expenditure.des_en: The rate at which the body burns calories while at rest. Resting energy expenditure accounts for 60%–75% of the daily calories burned.

restless legs syndrome.des_en: Achy or unpleasant feelings in the legs associated with a need to move. Most prominent at night, making it hard to fall asleep or stay asleep.

retinal detachment.des_en: A condition in which the retina separates from the choroid (the back of the eye) and leads to a loss of vision.

retrieval.des_en: The act of recalling previously learned information, involving the reactivation of particular nerve-cell pathways in the brain related to that piece of information.

retrograde ejaculation.des_en: An adverse effect of both prostate surgery and some medications that causes semen to flow back into the bladder rather than out through the penis.

retrospective study.des_en: A research method that looks for possible causes for a current disease by examining a study population's past habits.

revascularization.des_en: Restoration of blood flow to areas of heart muscle affected by coronary artery disease by means of coronary artery bypass surgery or angioplasty.

reward insufficiency theory.des_en: The theory that some people turn to addiction to compensate for an inability to sufficiently experience pleasure.

reward pathway.des_en: An interrelated set of brain regions that are all involved in recognizing, experiencing, and remembering pleasurable or rewarding events.

rheumatologist.des_en: A medical doctor trained to diagnose and treat disorders involving inflammation of the joints and other parts of the musculoskeletal system.

rheumatology.des_en: The branch of medicine devoted to the study and treatment of diseases marked by inflammation, degeneration, or metabolic problems of the connective tissues (particularly the joints and related structures).

rhytidectomy.des_en: A surgical procedure that involves removing excess skin and tightening the underlying muscle to correct sagging around the jaws, jowls, and neck. Does not include work on the eyes or forehead. Commonly known as a face lift.

right atrium.des_en: The right upper chamber of the heart; it receives partially deoxygenated blood as it returns from the body's tissues and moves it into the right ventricle for distribution to the lungs.

right coronary artery.des_en: One of the principal coronary arteries that supplies blood to the heart; this vessel supplies the right and lower part of the heart.

right ventricle.des_en: The right lower chamber of the heart; it receives blood from the right atrium for distribution to the lungs.

Rinne test.des_en: A simple hearing test that uses a tuning fork to determine what type of hearing loss a person has.

risky drinking.des_en: Drinking that increases the chances of adverse consequences; drinking more than guidelines on moderate drinking suggest.

RLS.des_en: Abbreviation for restless legs syndrome, an achy or unpleasant feelings in the legs associated with a need to move. Most prominent at night, making it hard to fall asleep or stay asleep.

rods.des_en: Light-sensitive cells in the retina that respond best in darkness and dim light.

root.des_en: The portion of the tooth below the gum line.

root canal therapy.des_en: A procedure in which diseased pulp tissue is removed from the pulp chamber and root canal and the area is sealed off.

rosacea.des_en: A skin condition that enlarges blood vessels in the face, causing redness of the nose and other parts of the face.

roughage.des_en: Indigestible dietary fiber found in grains, fruits, vegetables, and other foods. Roughage is thought to help prevent conditions such as constipation.

ruptured disk.des_en: When part of a spinal disk bulges out of a tear or weak spot in the disk’s tough outer shell. Also known as prolapsed disk or herniated disk.

SAD.des_en: Abbreviation for seasonal affective disorder, sadness and depression brought on by a lack of exposure to sunlight. SAD usually appears in the fall or winter and subsides in the spring.

saphenous vein.des_en: A superficial blood vessel that extends from the thigh to the calf; it can be removed and used as a coronary bypass graft.

satisficer.des_en: A person who can make a choice and be satisfied with it when presented with an option that meets his or her standards, without needing to examine all options or find the absolute best.

saturated fat.des_en: A type of fat found in animal foods such as meat, poultry skin, butter, and whole-milk dairy products, as well in as palm and coconut oils. A diet high in saturated fat tends to raise blood levels of unhealthy low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol.

sausage digit.des_en: A toe or finger swollen and red along its entire length.

scapulothoracic joint.des_en: A shoulder joint that connects the scapula to the ribs at the back of the chest.

Schlemm's canal.des_en: A circular drainage system in the eye located where the clear cornea, white sclera, and colored iris meet to form an angle.

scintigraphy.des_en: A diagnostic technique based on the detection of energy emitted by radioactive substances injected into the body; also called radionuclide scanning.

scintillations.des_en: The perception of flashing lights or lines that sometimes occurs during the aura of a migraine headache.

scleral buckling.des_en: A surgical technique that indents the sclera and choroid to reattach the retina.

scleroderma.des_en: An autoimmune disease in which the skin thickens and hardens; sometimes other parts of the body are affected, and joint pain may result.

scurvy.des_en: A disease caused by vitamin C deficiency, characterized by bruising, poor wound healing, bleeding of the gums, and loosened teeth.

seasonal affective disorder.des_en: Sadness and depression brought on by a lack of exposure to sunlight. Seasonal affective disorder usually appears in the fall or winter and subsides in the spring. sometimes referred to as SAD.

sebaceous gland.des_en: A gland that opens into a terminal hair follicle; it secretes sebum, the natural oily conditioner of hair.

secondary hypertension.des_en: High blood pressure that has an identifiable, often correctable, cause such as kidney disease, hyperthyroidism, sleep apnea and other conditions.

secondary osteoporosis.des_en: Bone loss associated with an identifiable medical condition, treatment with certain drugs, or immobility.

sed rate.des_en: Shorthand for erythrocyte sedimentation rate—a test involving red blood cells used to check for different infections, inflammations, and cancers.

selective estrogen receptor modulators.des_en: Chemically synthesized drugs that mimic estrogen in some tissues but act to block estrogen’s effects in others.

selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.des_en: Antidepressants that block the reuptake of serotonin into the neurons that released it, leaving more serotonin available to nerve cell receptors. Commonly used to treat depression and other mood disorders.

self-help group.des_en: A group of people who meet to discuss and offer assistance to one another with the goal of providing social support for changing troubling behavior patterns.

senile dementia.des_en: Diagnosis once given to people over 65 with dementia.

sensate focus techniques.des_en: A set of structured exercises that sex therapists use to help couples focus on the sensual aspects of physical contact without pressure to achieve orgasm.

sensorineural hearing loss.des_en: Permanent hearing loss caused by damage to the cochlea, hair cells, or auditory nerve.

SERMs.des_en: Abbreviation for selective estrogen receptor modulators, chemically synthesized drugs that mimic estrogen in some tissues but act to block estrogen’s effects in others.

seroma.des_en: A pocket of lymphatic fluid that builds up at an incision after surgery.

serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibi.des_en: Antidepressants that slow the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine into the neurons that released these substances, leaving more serotonin and norepinephrine available to nerve cell receptors. Commonly used to treat depression and other mood disorders.

sesamoiditis.des_en: A painful inflammation in and around two small bones known as sesamoids, located beneath the base of the big toe, at the ball of the foot.

set.des_en: A specific number of repetitions of an exercise done as a group.

sigmoid colon.des_en: Section of the colon leading to the rectum that makes an S-shaped curve.

sigmoidoscopy.des_en: Internal examination of the rectum and sigmoid colon using a flexible viewing tube inserted through the anus.

signature strengths.des_en: Character strengths such as curiosity, integrity, and modesty that people identify with, appreciate having, and enjoy using.

sildenafil citrate.des_en: The active ingredient in Viagra. It blocks the breakdown of cyclic guanosine monophosphate, a chemical necessary for an erection.

silent heart attack.des_en: Heart attack that occurs without pain or symptoms; occurs most commonly in the elderly or in people with diabetes.

silent ischemia.des_en: Shortage of oxygen delivery to the heart muscle that causes no symptoms.

single-photon absorptiometry.des_en: A test using gamma rays to measure bone density, usually in the forearm.

sinus rhythm.des_en: The heart's normal rate and rhythm.

skeletal muscles.des_en: Muscles attached to bones throughout the body that allow voluntary movement to occur.

skin resurfacing.des_en: Any of several approaches to improve skin texture, tone, wrinkle appearance, and discolorations by promoting new collagen and epidermal growth. Chemical peels, dermabrasion, microdermabrasion, and laser procedures are skin-resurfacing techniques.

sleep apnea.des_en: Temporary pause in breathing during sleep, lasting at least 10 seconds and associated with a fall in blood oxygen or arousal from sleep. Obstructive sleep apnea is caused by an obstruction in the airway blocking air flow; central sleep apnea occurs when the brain temporarily stops sending signals to the muscles that control breathing.

sleep architecture.des_en: The pattern made when sleep stages are charted on a hypnogram.

sleep paralysis.des_en: A feeling of paralysis that may occur during the transition between wakefulness and sleep if the REM sleep stage begins before a person is fully asleep; classically associated with narcolepsy.

sleep spindles.des_en: On an electroencephalogram (EEG), brief rhythmic bursts of activity that appear during stage 2 sleep.

slipped vertebra.des_en: Forward displacement of a vertebra in relation to the vertebra immediately below; also called spondylolisthesis.

slit lamp.des_en: An instrument that magnifies internal structures of the eye with the aid of a thin beam of light. Also called a biomicroscope.

slow-twitch fiber.des_en: One of two main types of skeletal muscle fibers. Slow-twitch fibers are recruited most heavily for endurance (aerobic) exercises. See also fast-twitch fiber.

slow-wave sleep.des_en: Sleep stages 3 and 4; during slow-wave sleep the brain becomes less responsive to external stimuli.

Snellen chart.des_en: The conventional eye chart used to test vision with lines of block letters in progressively smaller sizes.

somatization.des_en: Bodily symptoms that have no clear physical cause or are out of proportion to a given ailment, and may stem from psychological causes.

sorbitol.des_en: A crystalline sugar alcohol used as a sweetening agent.

spacer.des_en: A hollow chamber into which inhaled medicines can be squirted before inhalation. Spacers are used with metered-dose inhalers to help deliver medicine effectively to the bronchial tubes and to reduce the amount of medicine left behind on the tongue and throat.

spinal fusion.des_en: A procedure to attach two or more vertebrae with a bone graft in order to eliminate motion and relieve pain.

spinal stenosis.des_en: A narrowing of the spinal canal, which can result in compression of nerve roots.

spinal tap.des_en: Use of a hollow needle to withdraw fluid from the lower part of the spinal canal for testing. Also called a lumbar puncture.

spinous process.des_en: The lever-like backward projection extending off each vertebra, to which muscles and ligaments are attached.

splenic flexure syndrome.des_en: A painful spasm in the left upper abdomen below the rib cage, produced by areas of trapped gas in the colon.

spongy bone.des_en: Porous bone, also called trabecular bone, often found at the center of long bones.

SSRIs.des_en: Abbreviation for selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, antidepressants that block the reuptake of serotonin into the neurons that released it, leaving more serotonin available to nerve cell receptors. Commonly used to treat depression and other mood disorders.

stable angina.des_en: Angina pectoris (chest pain with exertion or stress) that is well-controlled with medicines and lifestyle changes.

stable coronary artery disease.des_en: Narrowings in the heart arteries that cause angina pectoris in a predictable and stable pattern over time (for example, after walking a certain distance).

stages of change.des_en: A model for how people make changes in their lives. According to this model, changes in behavior are made gradually and in relatively distinct stages.

standardized extract.des_en: An herbal product in which what is believed to be the active ingredient meets an established standard of strength.

statins.des_en: Cholesterol-lowering medications that interfere with the enzyme 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A reductase; also known as HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors. Statins work by changing the way the liver processes lipids.

stent.des_en: A wire mesh device inserted into an artery to prop it open once a blockage has been cleared by angioplasty.

steroids.des_en: Another term for corticosteroids—steroid medications made to mimic hormones produced naturally by the adrenal glands. They are used to treat a wide range of health problems.

stimulant.des_en: A substance that speeds up chemical reactions inside cells and provides a boost of energy. Examples include caffeine and amphetamine.

stratum corneum.des_en: The most superficial layer of the epidermis.

strength.des_en: The ability of muscles to exert force.

strength training.des_en: Popular term for exercises that harness resistance supplied by body weight, free weights such as dumbbells or weighted cuffs, resistance bands, or specialized machines; also known as resistance training or weight training.

streptokinase.des_en: A thrombolytic (clot-dissolving) agent designed to dissolve the blood clots that block an artery during a heart attack or stroke.

stress fracture.des_en: A hairline crack in a bone that usually occurs from overuse; left untreated, this may lead to displacement of the bones.

stress response.des_en: Physiological changes, such as quickened breathing and heartbeat and increased blood pressure, brought on by stress hormones released in response to a real or perceived threat to safety. Also called the fight-or-flight response.

stress test.des_en: A diagnostic test in which cardiovascular measurements such as heart rate, blood pressure, and electrical activity are recorded while the heart is being stressed (usually by having the person exercise on a treadmill or bicycle).

stressors.des_en: Stressful events or circumstances that may be real or perceived threats to equilibrium and well-being.

subacute thyroiditis.des_en: A painful version of thyroid inflammation caused by viral infection. Symptoms are flu-like and include fever, muscle aches and pains, and a painful, swollen thyroid gland. Also known as de Quervain’s thyroiditis.

subdural hematoma.des_en: A blood clot in the brain between the cerebral cortex and the dura.

subendocardial myocytes.des_en: Heart-muscle cells on the inside of the heart chambers; these cells are highly susceptible to damage from blockages of the major coronary arteries.

substance abuse.des_en: Continued substance use despite substance-related social or interpersonal problems.

substance dependence.des_en: A condition characterized by excessive and often compulsive substance use, impaired control over substance use, continued use of substances despite adverse consequences, and withdrawal symptoms that emerge when the substance use is discontinued.

subunit vaccines.des_en: Vaccines using only part of a microbe—the antigens—to elicit an immune response; these vaccines tend to cause fewer adverse reactions than vaccines which contain the whole microbe.

sulcus.des_en: The V-shaped hollow at the margin of the tooth and gum.

sulfonylureas.des_en: A class of medications that works by stimulating the pancreas to produce more insulin.

sundowning.des_en: Confusion or disorientation beginning at the end of the day and continuing into the night; often occurs in people with Alzheimer's disease or vascular dementia.

superior vena cava.des_en: The major vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the upper body to the heart.

superset.des_en: Two or more exercises combined for a more vigorous workout. During a superset, all the reps of exercise A are performed and then all the reps of exercise B before resting.

suprachiasmatic nucleus.des_en: A small group of nerve cells located in the hypothalamus that controls the sleep/wake cycle.

supraventricular tachycardia.des_en: An abnormally fast heartbeat originating in heart tissue above the ventricles.

symptom-limited exercise stress test.des_en: Exercise test, usually using a treadmill or bicycle, that increases in difficulty at set stages and is stopped when the person develops chest pain, breathlessness, or extreme fatigue.

synovium.des_en: A thin membrane that lines joint capsules and produces synovial fluid.

systemic lupus erythematosus.des_en: A connective tissue disease that can affect internal organs, nervous system, skin, and joints.

systolic blood pressure.des_en: The first or top number in a blood pressure reading; a measure of the pressure blood exerts against arterial walls when the heart contracts.

systolic heart failure.des_en: The inability of the heart to pump blood efficiently due to weakening and enlargement of the ventricles. Systolic heart failure is usually caused by coronary artery disease, high blood pressure, and valvular heart disease.

T cell.des_en: Abbreviation for T lymphocyte, a type of white blood cell that is produced in the bone marrow and is part of the body’s immune system.

T lymphocyte.des_en: A type of white blood cell that is produced in the bone marrow and is part of the body’s immune system. Also called a T cell.

tamsulosin.des_en: A drug used to treat symptoms of an enlarged prostate gland. It relieves constriction of the urethra and improves urine flow by relaxing the smooth muscle tissues in the capsule that surrounds the prostate. Unlike other drugs in this class, tamsulosin does not decrease blood pressure.

tangles.des_en: Also called neurofibrillary tangles—twisted strands of proteins that are found inside the dead or dying nerve cells of people with Alzheimer's disease.

tarsal coalition.des_en: An inherited condition in which two bones of the foot are fused together; can result in rigid flat feet.

TDD.des_en: Abbreviation for telecommunications device for the deaf—machinery that allows a person who is deaf or hard of hearing to send and receive typed messages over the telephone.

telecommunications devices for the deaf.des_en: Machinery that allows a person who is deaf or hard of hearing to send and receive typed messages over the telephone.

tempo.des_en: When applied to exercise, the count for key movements in an exercise.
