temporal arteritis.des_en: Also called cranial arteritis and giant cell arteritis—inflammation and damage to blood vessels supplying blood to the head and neck.

temporal lobe.des_en: One of the four major subdivisions of the two hemispheres of the brain’s cerebral cortex. The temporal lobe plays a role in hearing, long-term memory, and behavior.

tendon.des_en: A cord of collagen fibers that connect a muscle to a bone.

TENS.des_en: Abbreviation for transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation—the use of low-voltage electrical current (through electrodes placed on the skin) to provide pain-suppressing stimulation.

terazosin.des_en: A drug used to treat symptoms of an enlarged prostate gland. It relieves constriction of the urethra and improves urine flow by relaxing the smooth muscle tissue in the capsule that surrounds the prostate.

thalamus.des_en: A brain structure that relays sensory information to other parts of the brain; also plays a role in memory consolidation.

theta waves.des_en: A pattern of brain waves on an electroencephalogram (EEG) characteristic of light, stage 1 sleep.

thiazolidinediones.des_en: A class of oral medication that improves sensitivity to insulin.

thrombolytic agents.des_en: Agents or medications that dissolve blood clots and restore blood flow through a blocked artery; used to treat myocardial infarction, ischemic stroke, and pulmonary embolism. Also called clot busters. Examples include tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) and streptokinase.

thunderclap headache.des_en: A sudden, excruciating headache that may be the result of bleeding in the head.

thymus.des_en: A specialized organ of the immune system located in the upper-middle chest where T cells mature.

thyroid gland.des_en: A two-lobed gland located in the front of the neck below the larynx (voice box). It secretes hormones that help regulate the body's metabolism and calcium balance.

thyroid hormone.des_en: Two iodine-containing hormones called thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). They help regulate the body's metabolism and calcium balance.

thyroid-stimulating hormone.des_en: A hormone secreted into the bloodstream by the pituitary gland that stimulates the thyroid gland. Doctors measure levels of TSH to determine whether a person’s thyroid hormone levels are normal.

TIA.des_en: Abbreviation for transient ischemic attack, a brain attack that resolves on its own within 24 hours. Sometimes called a mini-stroke, a TIA is often an early warning sign of an impending stroke.

tic douloureux.des_en: Pain from a disorder of the trigeminal nerve, the chief sensory nerve of the face. Also called trigeminal neuralgia.

ticlopidine.des_en: An antiplatelet drug that prevents the formation of blood clots.

tinea capitis.des_en: An itchy condition of the scalp caused by a fungal infection. Also known as ringworm.

tinnitus.des_en: A ringing in the ears or some other sound that has no external cause.

tissue plasminogen activator.des_en: A clot-dissolving enzyme produced naturally in the blood vessels and artificially produced as a medication. Tissue plasminogen activator (commonly known as tPA) is used to break down blood clots in the treatment of heart attack, ischemic stroke, and pulmonary embolism. tPA must be used within a few hours after symptoms begin.

tolerable upper intake level.des_en: The highest amount of a nutrient deemed likely to have no harmful health effects for almost all healthy people when taken consistently.

toll-like receptors.des_en: One class of pattern-recognition receptors, found on the surfaces of the cells of the innate immune system.

tonometry.des_en: A glaucoma screening test that measures pressure inside the eye.

tooth decay.des_en: Infectious disease that attacks the teeth. Also called dental caries.

topical.des_en: Pertaining to an external surface of the body, such as the skin, mouth, vagina, or anus; often used to describe the administration of medicine that is applied directly to such a surface.

toxic nodular goiter.des_en: An enlarged thyroid gland with nodules that produce excess thyroid hormone. This type of goiter is to blame for hyperthyroidism in many people over 60.

toxoid vaccines.des_en: Vaccines that protect against harmful bacterial toxins. These vaccines contain toxins that have been detoxified and rendered inactive.

tPA.des_en: Abbreviation for tissue plasminogen activator, a clot-dissolving enzyme produced naturally in the blood vessels and artificially produced as a medication. tPA is used to break down blood clots in the treatment of heart attack, ischemic stroke, and pulmonary embolism. tPA must be used within a few hours after symptoms begin.

trabecular bone.des_en: Bone tissue arranged in a meshwork of thin plates or beams that is commonly found at the center of long bones and that composes a large part of the hip and vertebrae. Also called cancellous bone or spongy bone.

trabecular meshwork.des_en: A system of fine, mesh-like tissue in the anterior chamber of the eye through which aqueous humor drains; located in the angle where the clear cornea, white sclera, and colored iris join.

trabeculectomy.des_en: A standard surgical procedure for glaucoma that creates a new channel for fluid drainage from the anterior chamber to the sub-conjunctival space.

trabeculoplasty.des_en: A laser procedure that burns small holes on the eye's trabecular meshwork to ease the flow of aqueous humor from the eye.

trace mineral.des_en: A mineral that is required only in tiny amounts in the diet to maintain health; the principal trace minerals are chromium, copper, selenium, sulfur, and zinc.

trans fatty acid.des_en: A type of fat made during hydrogenation of liquid vegetable oil. Trans fats are found in many solid margarines, commercially prepared baked goods, and fried foods in many restaurants. Trans fats increase harmful low-density lipoprotein, decrease protective high-density lipoprotein, and promote blood clotting and inflammation. Also known as trans fat.

transcranial Doppler scanning.des_en: An ultrasound technique that makes images of the major arteries at the base of the brain.

transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulat.des_en: The use of low-voltage electrical current (through electrodes placed on the skin) to provide pain-suppressing stimulation.

transferrin saturation.des_en: A measure of iron circulating in the blood.

transient ischemic attack.des_en: A brain attack that resolves on its own within 24 hours. Sometimes called a mini-stroke or TIA, a transient ischemic attack is often an early warning sign of an impending stroke.

transmural infarction.des_en: Heart attack that destroys the entire thickness of a section of heart muscle.

transrectal ultrasonography.des_en: A procedure that uses sound waves to create an image of the prostate gland as a means of detecting cancer. Sound waves are directed to the prostate from a probe inserted in the rectum.

transurethral incision of the prostate.des_en: An operation used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlarged prostate gland) in which incisions are made in prostate tissue to relieve pressure on the urethra and ease urinary difficulties.

transurethral microwave thermotherapy.des_en: A heat therapy for benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlarged prostate gland) that uses microwaves to destroy prostate tissue that obstructs urine flow.

transurethral needle ablation.des_en: A procedure that uses radio waves to heat and destroy cells in the prostate gland that are obstructing the urethra.

transurethral resection of the prostate.des_en: An operation used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlarged prostate gland) in which excess prostate tissue is surgically removed.

transverse processes.des_en: The ringlike projection on each side of a vertebra to which muscles and ligaments are attached and, in the chest area, to which the ribs are connected.

traumatic grief.des_en: A prolonged, intense reaction to bereavement that affects one in 10 people who lose a loved one. Key signs are inability to accept the death; frequent nightmares and intrusive, upsetting memories; detachment from others; constant yearning for the deceased; and excessive loneliness. Also known as complicated grief or chronic grief.

tricyclic antidepressant.des_en: A class of medications that relieve depression by interfering with the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine by neurons in the brain and spinal cord. At low doses, they are effective as pain medicines.

trigger point.des_en: A tender area that, when stimulated, also elicits pain elsewhere in the body.

triiodothyronine.des_en: One of two types of major thyroid hormone manufactured by the thyroid gland. It contains three iodine atoms. Also known as T3.

triptans.des_en: A class of medications that work by constricting blood vessels in the head and perhaps by inhibiting inflammation.

trochlea.des_en: A groove in front of the femur where the patella moves as the knee bends and straightens.

troponins.des_en: Proteins found in heart muscle that leak into the circulation during a heart attack or other heart injury.

trust.des_en: A legal entity in which assets are gathered during a person’s lifetime. That person may control distributions directly or through trustees elected to carry out wishes at a time or point specified. After death, remaining assets are distributed to beneficiaries.

TSH.des_en: Abbreviation for thyroid-stimulating hormone, a hormone secreted into the bloodstream by the pituitary gland that stimulates the thyroid gland. Doctors measure levels of TSH to determine whether a person’s thyroid hormone levels are normal.

tunica albuginea.des_en: The dense fibrous membrane surrounding each corpus cavernosum and the corpus spongiosum in the penis.

tympanometry.des_en: A test of the eardrum's motion and pressure in the middle ear. Also known as impedance testing.

type 1 diabetes.des_en: A type of diabetes, a chronic condition that affects the way the body's tissues use sugar (glucose), their main source of fuel. Once called juvenile-onset diabetes and insulin-dependent diabetes. People with this form of diabetes don't make enough insulin, a hormone that controls the movement of glucose into cells. They must rely on insulin injections.

type 1 osteoporosis.des_en: Bone loss due to estrogen decline associated with menopause.

type 2 diabetes.des_en: A type of diabetes, a chronic condition that affects the way the body's tissues use sugar (glucose), their main source of fuel. Once called adult -onset diabetes and non-insulin-dependent diabetes. People with this form of the disease have tissues that either resist the effects of insulin (a hormone that control the movement of sugar into cells) or the body doesn't produce enough insulin. It is initially treated with diet, exercise, weight-loss if needed, and oral medications.

unopposed estrogen.des_en: Estrogen taken without an accompanying progestogen.

unresolved losses.des_en: Personal losses that are not acknowledged and mourned. Many mental health experts believe that reactions to these losses crop up later, often skewing a person’s response to an entirely different loss.

unsaturated fat.des_en: Healthy dietary fats from plant sources such as vegetable oils, nuts, and whole grains, as well as from fatty fish. Includes monounsaturated fat and polyunsaturated fat.

unstable angina.des_en: Chest pain that occurs or worsens in frequency, severity, or duration when a person is at rest or engaging in mild activity.

upper airway resistance syndrome.des_en: Inhalation that requires undue extra exertion; this extra work may cause insomnia and daytime sleepiness.

upper esophageal sphincter.des_en: Muscular valve located at the upper portion of the esophagus that opens to allow food or liquid to enter the digestive system.

urethral hypermobility.des_en: Movement of the urethra out of place when abdominal pressure increases, leading to stress incontinence.

urgency.des_en: The sudden and uncontrollable need to urinate or defecate.

urinary frequency.des_en: Routinely needing to urinate more than eight times during the day or more than twice at night.

uvula.des_en: A small, fleshy flap of tissue that hangs from the back of the throat over the root of the tongue.

uvulopalatopharyngoplasty.des_en: A surgical treatment for obstructive sleep apnea that involves removing the uvula, the tonsils, and a rim of loose tissue at the back of the soft palate.

vacuum erection devices.des_en: Various manual or battery-operated pumps that a man can use to draw blood into the penis to create an erection.

valves.des_en: Structures consisting of leaflets that divide the chambers of the heart and prevent the backflow of blood from one chamber to another during contraction of the heart.

variant angina pectoris.des_en: Also called Prinzmetal's angina, these are attacks of chest pain caused by spasms of one or more coronary arteries almost always while a person is at rest.

vascular dementia.des_en: Dementia caused by narrowing or blockage of blood vessels in the brain or by a stroke or series of tiny strokes. Also called multi-infarct dementia.

vascular surgery.des_en: An operation to improve blood flow either by repairing leaks in blood vessels or by rerouting arteries to bypass blockages.

vasoconstrictor.des_en: A substance or condition, such as drugs, cold, fear, and nicotine, that causes blood vessels to narrow and thus de­creases the flow of blood.

vasodilator.des_en: A substance or condition that causes blood vessels to open wider and increase the flow of blood.

venous leak.des_en: Seepage of blood out of a vein.

ventilator.des_en: Machine that inflates the lungs with oxygen.

ventricular arrhythmia.des_en: Abnormal heart rhythm that starts in the lower chambers of the heart; this rhythm disturbance can occur as a complication of a heart attack and impairs the heart's pumping ability.

ventricular fibrillation.des_en: A deadly heart rhythm in which the ventricles contract independently of the atria and in a chaotic manner.

ventricular myocardium.des_en: Heart muscle that makes up the lower chambers of the heart.

ventricular rupture.des_en: Break in the heart muscle that allows blood to escape into the pericardial sac.

ventricular septal defect.des_en: One or more holes in the septum, the muscular wall separating the right and left sides of the heart.

ventricular tachycardia.des_en: A very fast heartbeat that starts in the ventricles. Ventricular tachycardia can be deadly if it renders the heart unable to pump enough blood to the body.

vertebral artery.des_en: One of two blood vessels that run up the back of the neck and join at the base of the skull to form the basilar artery. The vertebral arteries carry blood from the heart to the brain.

vertebroplasty.des_en: A minimally invasive procedure to stabilize compressed vertebrae and alleviate pain. A needle is inserted into the compressed portion of a vertebra and surgical cement is injected to support the vertebra and prevent further collapse.

very low-calorie diet.des_en: A weight-loss diet that allows 800 or fewer calories per day (usually followed under medical supervision).

very-low-density lipoprotein.des_en: A lipoprotein that transports triglyceride manufactured in the liver to fat tissue in the body. VLDL eventually becomes low-density lipoprotein (LDL) after the triglyceride has been removed.

vestibular system.des_en: The balance organs, located in the labyrinth in the inner ear.

virtues.des_en: Core characteristics that are universally valued by philosophers and religions across time and cultures, such as wisdom and courage.

virulent.des_en: A disease or condition that is highly infectious or dangerous or rapidly progressing.

visual cortex.des_en: The part of the occipital lobe in the brain that processes visual stimuli.

visualized laser-assisted prostatectomy.des_en: A technique used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlarged prostate gland) that allows the surgeon to view the prostate directly while it is being shrunk by a laser beam.

vital signs.des_en: Measurements that indicate how well the body is functioning, including pulse rate, respiration (breathing rate), temperature, and blood pressure.

vitamin D.des_en: A hormone that plays a key role in ensuring the absorption of calcium from the intestines.

vitrectomy.des_en: A microsurgical procedure in which part of the vitreous humor of the eye is removed and then replaced with sterile saline or some other fluid.

VLDL.des_en: Abbreviation for very-low-density lipoprotein, a lipoprotein that transports triglyceride manufactured in the liver to fat tissue in the body. VLDL eventually becomes low-density lipoprotein (LDL) after the triglyceride has been removed.

VO2 max.des_en: The body’s maximum capacity for oxygen consumption during peak exertion. Also known as aerobic power, maximal oxygen consumption, or cardiorespiratory endurance capacity.

volatile oils.des_en: Unstable components of a preparation that evaporate easily.

VSD.des_en: Abbreviation for ventricular septal defect—one or more holes in the septum, the muscular wall separating the right and left sides of the heart.

vulvar vestibulitis.des_en: Inflammation of the tissue around the opening of the vagina that makes sexual activity painful.

vulvodynia.des_en: Pain in the vulva that may or may not be brought on by touch or pressure.

wall stress.des_en: Force on the wall of the heart muscle caused by pressure inside the heart's pumping chamber; excessive wall stress can impair the heart's ability to pump and increase the heart's need for oxygen.

warfarin.des_en: An anticoagulant drug that prevents blood clotting; people taking it must have regular blood tests to determine that their blood does not clot too readily or too slowly.

Weber test.des_en: A hearing test that uses a tuning fork to diagnose one-sided hearing loss.

Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.des_en: An irreversible state of acute confusion and amnesia that develops in alcoholics as a result of malnutrition-related thiamine deficiency.

Wernicke's area.des_en: The brain region responsible for the comprehension of speech.

whiplash.des_en: The popular term for muscle and ligament damage resulting from rapid and extreme extension and flexion of the neck. The term is also used for the accident causing the injury, most often a rear-end motor vehicle accident.

white-coat hypertension.des_en: Blood pressure that is elevated in a doctor’s office but is normal at home.

will.des_en: A legal document that describes what should be done with a person's assets after his or her death.

working memory.des_en: A type of short-term memory process that involves temporarily storing and manipulating information.

YAG capsulotomy.des_en: A laser technique to correct blurred vision caused by cloudiness that may develop in the skin of the cataract left in the eye after cataract surgery; a laser is used to create a hole in the membrane to allow light to enter clearly focused onto the retina.

yohimbine.des_en: An extract of the bark of a West African tree sometimes used in treating erectile dysfunction. Yohimbine appears to increase blood flow to the penis and prevent blood from leaving it too quickly.

zonules.des_en: Thin, gelatinous ligaments that attach the lens to the ciliary body and support the lens centrally behind the pupil.

zoonotic disease.des_en: An infectious disease that is transmissible under normal conditions from animals to humans.
